values.description:
There is a [flaky test failure of `UNIT_LogPlay_TEST`](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/GazeboDefault/job/gazebo-ci-default-homebrew-amd64/70/testReport/junit/(root)/LogPlay_TEST/Accessors/) caused by an uninitialized `initialIterations` variable (see valgrind output below):

~~~
==15526== Conditional jump or move depends on uninitialised value(s)
==15526==    at 0x414B2A: testing::AssertionResult testing::internal::CmpHelperEQ<unsigned long, unsigned int>(char const*, char const*, unsigned long const&, unsigned int const&) (gtest.h:1448)
==15526==    by 0x40E4BA: Compare<long unsigned int, unsigned int> (gtest.h:1485)
==15526==    by 0x40E4BA: LogPlay_TEST_Accessors_Test::TestBody() (LogPlay_TEST.cc:102)
==15526==    by 0x435C42: HandleSehExceptionsInMethodIfSupported<testing::Test, void> (gtest.cc:2079)
==15526==    by 0x435C42: void testing::internal::HandleExceptionsInMethodIfSupported<testing::Test, void>(testing::Test*, void (testing::Test::*)(), char const*) (gtest.cc:2115)
==15526==    by 0x4284A6: testing::Test::Run() (gtest.cc:2152)
==15526==    by 0x428545: testing::TestInfo::Run() (gtest.cc:2327)
==15526==    by 0x42864C: testing::TestCase::Run() (gtest.cc:2445)
==15526==    by 0x4288DC: testing::internal::UnitTestImpl::RunAllTests() (gtest.cc:4316)
==15526==    by 0x428BDD: HandleSehExceptionsInMethodIfSupported<testing::internal::UnitTestImpl, bool> (gtest.cc:2079)
==15526==    by 0x428BDD: HandleExceptionsInMethodIfSupported<testing::internal::UnitTestImpl, bool> (gtest.cc:2115)
==15526==    by 0x428BDD: testing::UnitTest::Run() (gtest.cc:3930)
==15526==    by 0x4076BE: RUN_ALL_TESTS (gtest.h:2288)
==15526==    by 0x4076BE: main (LogPlay_TEST.cc:464)
~~~

I've initialized a few others as well.
values.title: Initialize variables in LogPlayPrivate

values.description: We are using the [AnsiColor Plugin](https://wiki.jenkins-ci.org/display/JENKINS/AnsiColor+Plugin) in jenkins to colorize the console output so it looks like [this](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64_flaky/4/console) instead of [this](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64_flaky/5/console): ~~~ 491: [ RUN ] gzTest.Joint 491: [1;32m[Msg] [0m[1;32mWaiting for master.[0m[1;32m 491: [0m[1;32m[0m[1;32m[0m[1;32m[Msg] [0m[1;32mConnected to gazebo master @ [0m[1;32mhttp://127.0.0.1:11345[0m[1;32m 491: [0m[1;32m[0m[1;32m[0m[1;32m[Msg] [0m[1;32mPublicized address: [0m[1;32m172.23.2.252[0m[1;32m 491: [0m[1;32m[0m[1;32m[0m[ OK ] gzTest.Joint (1939 ms) ~~~ One drawback is that it makes the html form of the console output huge (120 MB instead of 4 MB). The following colored text expands to html with a ton of duplicate `` tags. ~~~ [Err] [SVGLoader.cc:666] Failed to load file /not/a/file.svg ~~~ ~~~ [Err] [ SVGLoader.cc : 666 ] Failed to load file /not/a/file.svg ~~~ Each `Console::log::<<` operator makes a separate `` tag. This PR makes a small change to reduce the number of `Console::log::<<` operators that are colorized by first streaming to a `std::stringstream` and then streaming to the `Console::log`. This reduced the console log from 120MB to 70MB in a [test build](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64_flaky/7/). I also discovered recently that the `check_test_ran.py` script doesn't work well with QTest's since those write blank junit files instead of not writing a file at all (in jenkins it looks like [this](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-gazebo5-homebrew-amd64/10/testReport/UNIT_ImagesView_TEST/xml/_empty_/)). So I've modified that script to write the `test_ran` output if the file size is zero. I also noticed that jenkins reports the time taken by QTest's to be super long ([over 9 hours for DataLogger_TEST](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/CI%20any%20jobs/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64_flaky/15/testReport/(root)/DataLogger_TEST/)). The `QBENCHMARK` seems to report time in `ms`, so I've added a divide by 1000 operation in the stylesheet that converts the qtest xml files to junit (752b959).
values.title: Reduce jenkins console log size, fix check_test_ran.py for QTest

summary.raw: We are using the [AnsiColor Plugin](https://wiki.jenkins-ci.org/display/JENKINS/AnsiColor+Plugin) in jenkins to colorize the console output so it looks like [this](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64_flaky/4/console) instead of [this](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64_flaky/5/console): ~~~ 491: [ RUN ] gzTest.Joint 491: [1;32m[Msg] [0m[1;32mWaiting for master.[0m[1;32m 491: [0m[1;32m[0m[1;32m[0m[1;32m[Msg] [0m[1;32mConnected to gazebo master @ [0m[1;32mhttp://127.0.0.1:11345[0m[1;32m 491: [0m[1;32m[0m[1;32m[0m[1;32m[Msg] [0m[1;32mPublicized address: [0m[1;32m172.23.2.252[0m[1;32m 491: [0m[1;32m[0m[1;32m[0m[ OK ] gzTest.Joint (1939 ms) ~~~ One drawback is that it makes the html form of the console output huge (120 MB instead of 4 MB). The following colored text expands to html with a ton of duplicate `` tags. ~~~ [Err] [SVGLoader.cc:666] Failed to load file /not/a/file.svg ~~~ ~~~ [Err] [ SVGLoader.cc : 666 ] Failed to load file /not/a/file.svg ~~~ Each `Console::log::<<` operator makes a separate `` tag. This PR makes a small change to reduce the number of `Console::log::<<` operators that are colorized by first streaming to a `std::stringstream` and then streaming to the `Console::log`. This reduced the console log from 120MB to 70MB in a [test build](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64_flaky/7/). I also discovered recently that the `check_test_ran.py` script doesn't work well with QTest's since those write blank junit files instead of not writing a file at all (in jenkins it looks like [this](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-gazebo5-homebrew-amd64/10/testReport/UNIT_ImagesView_TEST/xml/_empty_/)). So I've modified that script to write the `test_ran` output if the file size is zero. I also noticed that jenkins reports the time taken by QTest's to be super long ([over 9 hours for DataLogger_TEST](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/CI%20any%20jobs/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64_flaky/15/testReport/(root)/DataLogger_TEST/)). The `QBENCHMARK` seems to report time in `ms`, so I've added a divide by 1000 operation in the stylesheet that converts the qtest xml files to junit (752b959).
summary.html:
We are using the AnsiColor Plugin in jenkins to colorize the console output so it looks like this instead of this:

491: [ RUN      ] gzTest.Joint
491: [1;32m[Msg] [0m[1;32mWaiting for master.[0m[1;32m
491: [0m[1;32m[0m[1;32m[0m[1;32m[Msg] [0m[1;32mConnected to gazebo master @ [0m[1;32mhttp://127.0.0.1:11345[0m[1;32m
491: [0m[1;32m[0m[1;32m[0m[1;32m[Msg] [0m[1;32mPublicized address: [0m[1;32m172.23.2.252[0m[1;32m
491: [0m[1;32m[0m[1;32m[0m[       OK ] gzTest.Joint (1939 ms)

One drawback is that it makes the html form of the console output huge (120 MB instead of 4 MB). The following colored text expands to html with a ton of duplicate <span> tags.

[Err] [SVGLoader.cc:666] Failed to load file /not/a/file.svg

<b><span style="color: #CD0000;">[Err] </span></b>
<b><span style="color: #CD0000;">[</span></b>
<b><span style="color: #CD0000;">SVGLoader.cc</span></b>
<b><span style="color: #CD0000;">:</span></b>
<b><span style="color: #CD0000;">666</span></b>
<b><span style="color: #CD0000;">] </span></b>
<b><span style="color: #CD0000;">Failed to load file </span></b>
<b><span style="color: #CD0000;">/not/a/file.svg</span></b>

Each Console::log::<< operator makes a separate <span> tag. This PR makes a small change to reduce the number of Console::log::<< operators that are colorized by first streaming to a std::stringstream and then streaming to the Console::log. This reduced the console log from 120MB to 70MB in a test build.

I also discovered recently that the check_test_ran.py script doesn't work well with QTest's since those write blank junit files instead of not writing a file at all (in jenkins it looks like this). So I've modified that script to write the test_ran output if the file size is zero.

I also noticed that jenkins reports the time taken by QTest's to be super long (over 9 hours for DataLogger_TEST). The QBENCHMARK seems to report time in ms, so I've added a divide by 1000 operation in the stylesheet that converts the qtest xml files to junit (752b959).

values.description:
problem was that after a world reset, the returned force value was observed to accumulate until a certain point (time when the world was reset)  before returning the correct value.

It's mainly due to this check in [ODEJoint::SaveForce](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/97f52f361389fa980089fff670470def65f06cac/gazebo/physics/ode/ODEJoint.cc?fileviewer=file-view-default#ODEJoint.cc-1129) function. The `this->forceAppliedTime` simply needs to be reset

jenkins:

[gpu-none](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/CI%20any%20jobs/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-none/333/) - ok
values.title: Reset ODE joint force feedback after world reset -> gazebo7

summary.html:
problem was that after a world reset, the returned force value was observed to accumulate until a certain point (time when the world was reset) before returning the correct value.

It's mainly due to this check in ODEJoint::SaveForce function. The this->forceAppliedTime simply needs to be reset

This pull request fixes it :large_blue_circle:

summary.html:
Test RemoveBlankWorld is failing on default.

This pull request fixes it :large_blue_circle:

http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/CI%20any%20jobs/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-none/336/

values.reason: This uses the hacky fini approach, but I'll actually try something more elegant here.

values.description:
Test `RemoveBlankWorld` is failing on default because new classes `Atmosphere` and `Wind` have `shared_ptr`s to the world which are not being released.

There is currently an [open discussion](#!/osrf/gazebo_design/src/smart_pointers/smart_pointers/smart_pointers.md?at=smart_pointers&fileviewer=file-view-default) on how to improve the way we use smart pointers to avoid such problems in the future.

One ugly way to solve it is to  use `Fini` methods as was done in pull request #2256.

But since these classes were introduced in gazebo8, we have more room for experimentation. So I thought we could try some of the ideas on the design document. This pull request:

1. Gets rid of `shared_ptr` for Atmosphere and Wind.

1. The `World` is the one responsible for these classes' lifetimes, so it holds `unique_ptr`s to them. These classes should never outlive the world, and their lifespan is basically the same as the world's.

1. Atmosphere and Wind each hold a raw pointer to the world. They can use the object, but they should not delete it.

1. Other objects can hold raw pointers to Atmosphere and Wind, but no one should delete them.

1. Removed `Fini` and `Init` methods.

1. Destructors are empty because everything goes out of scope nicely, which is proven by the test being fixed.
values.title: Wind and atmosphere memory management

summary.raw:
Test `RemoveBlankWorld` is failing on default because new classes `Atmosphere` and `Wind` have `shared_ptr`s to the world which are not being released.

There is currently an [open discussion](#!/osrf/gazebo_design/src/smart_pointers/smart_pointers/smart_pointers.md?at=smart_pointers&fileviewer=file-view-default) on how to improve the way we use smart pointers to avoid such problems in the future.

One ugly way to solve it is to  use `Fini` methods as was done in pull request #2256.

But since these classes were introduced in gazebo8, we have more room for experimentation. So I thought we could try some of the ideas on the design document. This pull request:

1. Gets rid of `shared_ptr` for Atmosphere and Wind.

1. The `World` is the one responsible for these classes' lifetimes, so it holds `unique_ptr`s to them. These classes should never outlive the world, and their lifespan is basically the same as the world's.

1. Atmosphere and Wind each hold a raw pointer to the world. They can use the object, but they should not delete it.

1. Other objects can hold raw pointers to Atmosphere and Wind, but no one should delete them.

1. Removed `Fini` and `Init` methods.

1. Destructors are empty because everything goes out of scope nicely, which is proven by the test being fixed.
summary.html:
Test RemoveBlankWorld is failing on default because new classes Atmosphere and Wind have shared_ptrs to the world which are not being released.

There is currently an open discussion on how to improve the way we use smart pointers to avoid such problems in the future.

One ugly way to solve it is to use Fini methods as was done in pull request #2256.

But since these classes were introduced in gazebo8, we have more room for experimentation. So I thought we could try some of the ideas on the design document. This pull request:

  1. Gets rid of shared_ptr for Atmosphere and Wind.

  2. The World is the one responsible for these classes' lifetimes, so it holds unique_ptrs to them. These classes should never outlive the world, and their lifespan is basically the same as the world's.

  3. Atmosphere and Wind each hold a raw pointer to the world. They can use the object, but they should not delete it.

  4. Other objects can hold raw pointers to Atmosphere and Wind, but no one should delete them.

  5. Removed Fini and Init methods.

  6. Destructors are empty because everything goes out of scope nicely, which is proven by the test being fixed.

values.description:
Disclaimer: I tried to make this PR as small as possible, but fixing one thing breaks others... And it goes on like this for a while. So, sorry for the lots of changes. This touches a lot of important code and it might actually be breaking things we are not testing.

This is a continuation from pull request #2220.

It fixes issue #1928.

[homebrew](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/CI%20any%20jobs/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/342/testReport/) has no related failures

[trusty gpu](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/CI%20any%20jobs/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/323/testReport/) has no related failures

[ABI](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-abichecker-any_to_any-vivid-amd64/302/) is :large_blue_circle:
values.title: Clean up entities

values.description:
* need [this pull request from gazebo_models](#!/osrf/gazebo_models/pull-requests/177/aerodynamics-models/diff)
* redo pull request #2010 without the `keyhit` detector containing LGPL code
* ~~Need [this pull request for models](#!/osrf/gazebo_models/pull-requests/177/aerodynamics-models/diff).~~
* Adding a world file with the Cessna model and the liftDrag plugin. Controlled cessna flight by adding lift drag plugin response to control surface joint (cl only for now)
* change drag and re-orient sensor data before sending out to SIM_Gazebo
* use actual rotor speed by reducing rotorVelocitySlowdownSim from 10 to 1, and got rid of vertical and yaw coupling by adjusting cla and cda.
* [video](https://youtu.be/n_M5Vs5FBGY)
values.title: Aerodynamic updates

summary.raw:

* ~~Need [this pull request for models](#!/osrf/gazebo_models/pull-requests/177/aerodynamics-models/diff).~~
* Adding a world file with the Cessna model and the liftDrag plugin. Controlled cessna flight by adding lift drag plugin response to control surface joint (cl only for now)
* change drag and re-orient sensor data before sending out to SIM_Gazebo
* use actual rotor speed by reducing rotorVelocitySlowdownSim from 10 to 1, and got rid of vertical and yaw coupling by adjusting cla and cda.
* [video](https://youtu.be/n_M5Vs5FBGY)
summary.html:
• need this pull request from gazebo_models
  • redo pull request #2010 without the keyhit detector containing LGPL code
  • Need this pull request for models.
  • Adding a world file with the Cessna model and the liftDrag plugin. Controlled cessna flight by adding lift drag plugin response to control surface joint (cl only for now)
  • change drag and re-orient sensor data before sending out to SIM_Gazebo
  • use actual rotor speed by reducing rotorVelocitySlowdownSim from 10 to 1, and got rid of vertical and yaw coupling by adjusting cla and cda.
  • video

Undo / redo:

* Inserting a new joint between links / nested models

* Deleting a joint which was inserted

* Deleting a joint which already existed in the model

* Deleting a link / nested model which has joints attached

* Deleting joint from joint inspector

values.description:
# Implementation
Each subfolder of gazebo get's it's own header. That header is then included at the top of every file using gcc's ```-include``` option.

The naming convention is ```$subfolder_pch.hh``` which is transformed to ```$subfolder_pch.hh.out.gch```, and ```$subfodler_pch.hh.out``` is used with ```-include``` on all the files. The reason for the .out is to prevent the source files from finding the original ```$subfolder_pch.hh``` in the same directory before it found the pch in the build directory.

 - Currently using cmake macro called use_pch, but it may need some work.
 - Included some headers to be precompiled, but they are not optimized. Many expensive things are missing like Qt, OGRE.
 - The macro doesn't extend well for things like Qt which need lots of extra flags
 - Not extended to all subfolders yet (sensors, util, msgs, ... )

#Timing information
 - According to @_jrivero_,  "we can demonstrate that this code change improves the compilation time in at least 125 seconds in speedy (probably SDD) machines. In not so fast I/O machines (like kitt) this improvement is even better (~250s), around the 7%."

# How to test
```cmake .. -DUSE_PCH=ON```



Also there's a bit of trailing whitespace removed because vim does that for me.
values.title: Add basic support for gnu precompiled headers

summary.raw:
# Implementation
Each subfolder of gazebo get's it's own header. That header is then included at the top of every file using gcc's ```-include``` option.

The naming convention is ```$subfolder_pch.hh``` which is transformed to ```$subfolder_pch.hh.out.gch```, and ```$subfodler_pch.hh.out``` is used with ```-include``` on all the files. The reason for the .out is to prevent the source files from finding the original ```$subfolder_pch.hh``` in the same directory before it found the pch in the build directory.

 - Currently using cmake macro called use_pch, but it may need some work.
 - Included some headers to be precompiled, but they are not optimized. Many expensive things are missing like Qt, OGRE.
 - The macro doesn't extend well for things like Qt which need lots of extra flags
 - Not extended to all subfolders yet (sensors, util, msgs, ... )

#Timing information
 - According to @_jrivero_,  "we can demonstrate that this code change improves the compilation time in at least 125 seconds in speedy (probably SDD) machines. In not so fast I/O machines (like kitt) this improvement is even better (~250s), around the 7%."

# How to test
```cmake .. -DUSE_PCH=ON```



Also there's a bit of trailing whitespace removed because vim does that for me.
summary.html:
Implementation

Each subfolder of gazebo get's it's own header. That header is then included at the top of every file using gcc's -include option.

The naming convention is $subfolder_pch.hh which is transformed to $subfolder_pch.hh.out.gch, and $subfodler_pch.hh.out is used with -include on all the files. The reason for the .out is to prevent the source files from finding the original $subfolder_pch.hh in the same directory before it found the pch in the build directory.

  • Currently using cmake macro called use_pch, but it may need some work.
  • Included some headers to be precompiled, but they are not optimized. Many expensive things are missing like Qt, OGRE.
  • The macro doesn't extend well for things like Qt which need lots of extra flags
  • Not extended to all subfolders yet (sensors, util, msgs, ... )

#Timing information - According to @jrivero, "we can demonstrate that this code change improves the compilation time in at least 125 seconds in speedy (probably SDD) machines. In not so fast I/O machines (like kitt) this improvement is even better (~250s), around the 7%."

How to test

cmake .. -DUSE_PCH=ON

Also there's a bit of trailing whitespace removed because vim does that for me.

values.description:
I've been analyzing the lifecycle and ownership patterns of the `Event` classes ([design doc PR here](#!/osrf/gazebo_design/pull-requests/33)), and I noticed a few issues. This PR makes some internal changes that shouldn't affect any external code. The changes are organized by commits.

* a063142: Remove unused constructors for `event::Connection` and `event::ConnectionPrivate`

* 3b178e6: Make `ConnectionPrivate` not visible, use `unique_ptr` in `event::Connection`

* 98f43c9: Store copy of `boost::function` directly in `EventConnection` instead of wrapping in a smart pointer

* 91d232f: fix `Event` PIMPL pattern: the `EventPrivate` class was declared as visible, so it wasn't really following the PIMPL pattern. Since it was only holding one variable (`bool signaled`), it was moved to be a `protected` member of `Event`. A `unique_ptr` is then used to hold the `EventTPrivate` class. There was also a weird typo in the `Signal` function with 7 parameters.

* a0a0825: fix typo: Deleteing

The migration and changelog should probably be updated.
values.title: Event classes: some internal refactoring

summary.raw:
I've been analyzing the lifecycle and ownership patterns of the `Event` classes ([design doc PR here](#!/osrf/gazebo_design/pull-requests/33)), and I noticed a few issues. This PR makes some internal changes that shouldn't affect any external code. The changes are organized by commits.

* a063142: Remove unused constructors for `event::Connection` and `event::ConnectionPrivate`

* 3b178e6: Make `ConnectionPrivate` not visible, use `unique_ptr` in `event::Connection`

* 98f43c9: Store copy of `boost::function` directly in `EventConnection` instead of wrapping in a smart pointer

* 91d232f: fix `Event` PIMPL pattern: the `EventPrivate` class was declared as visible, so it wasn't really following the PIMPL pattern. Since it was only holding one variable (`bool signaled`), it was moved to be a `protected` member of `Event`. A `unique_ptr` is then used to hold the `EventTPrivate` class. There was also a weird typo in the `Signal` function with 7 parameters.

* a0a0825: fix typo: Deleteing

The migration and changelog should probably be updated.
summary.html:
I've been analyzing the lifecycle and ownership patterns of the Event classes (design doc PR here), and I noticed a few issues. This PR makes some internal changes that shouldn't affect any external code. The changes are organized by commits.

  • a063142: Remove unused constructors for event::Connection and event::ConnectionPrivate

  • 3b178e6: Make ConnectionPrivate not visible, use unique_ptr in event::Connection

  • 98f43c9: Store copy of boost::function directly in EventConnection instead of wrapping in a smart pointer

  • 91d232f: fix Event PIMPL pattern: the EventPrivate class was declared as visible, so it wasn't really following the PIMPL pattern. Since it was only holding one variable (bool signaled), it was moved to be a protected member of Event. A unique_ptr is then used to hold the EventTPrivate class. There was also a weird typo in the Signal function with 7 parameters.

  • a0a0825: fix typo: Deleteing

The migration and changelog should probably be updated.

values.description: We have found an issue in the atmosphere implementation after merging gazebo with our codebase. The adiabatic power must be computed in the constructor of AdiabaticAtmosphere and after loading SDF parameters. This pull request should fix this issue and adds a few related tests.
values.title: Fix adiabatic power computation

summary.raw: We have found an issue in the atmosphere implementation after merging gazebo with our codebase. The adiabatic power must be computed in the constructor of AdiabaticAtmosphere and after loading SDF parameters. This pull request should fix this issue and adds a few related tests.

values.description: Gravity and magnetic field strength were moved to be properties of the world rather than the physics engine in pull request #2090, but the old API's were not deprecated in gazebo7 (this may have been after feature freeze). So they are deprecated now, and all deprecation warnings fixed and some new tests added to `INTEGRATION_world`.
values.title: Deprecate PhysicsEngine::GetGravity() and MagneticField() in favor of World::* API's

summary.raw: Gravity and magnetic field strength were moved to be properties of the world rather than the physics engine in pull request #2090, but the old API's were not deprecated in gazebo7 (this may have been after feature freeze). So they are deprecated now, and all deprecation warnings fixed and some new tests added to `INTEGRATION_world`.
summary.html: Gravity and magnetic field strength were moved to be properties of the world rather than the physics engine in pull request #2090, but the old API's were not deprecated in gazebo7 (this may have been after feature freeze). So they are deprecated now, and all deprecation warnings fixed and some new tests added to INTEGRATION_world.

values.description:
This pull request makes it possible to:

* Align nested models 

* Align a mix of nested models and links, respecting selection order

* Sync selecting nested models in the 3D scene, model tree and schematic view:

    * Note that on the schematic view the nested models are broken into links, so some tricks were needed to make that work.

    * Without this fix, selecting a nested link in the schematic view also selects it in the 3d scene which opens way for it to be manipulated, we don't want that.

* Any combination of selecting links, joints and nested models, each selection coming from a different widget, including multi-select holding `Ctrl`, should work.

![syncselect.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/2664015414-syncselect.png)

I started writing integration tests for all of these but they can become very involved. So taking into account that many of these details might be changed due to user feedback, I thought we could just fix the issues now and write proper tests later.


[homebrew](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/CI%20any%20jobs/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/378/#showFailuresLink) didn't complain

[trusty nvidia](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/CI%20any%20jobs/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/356/#showFailuresLink) didn't complain
values.title: Model Editor: Select and align nested models

summary.raw:
This pull request makes it possible to:

* Align nested models 

* Align a mix of nested models and links, respecting selection order

* Sync selecting nested models in the 3D scene, model tree and schematic view:

    * Note that on the schematic view the nested models are broken into links, so some tricks were needed to make that work.

    * Without this fix, selecting a nested link in the schematic view also selects it in the 3d scene which opens way for it to be manipulated, we don't want that.

* Any combination of selecting links, joints and nested models, each selection coming from a different widget, including multi-select holding `Ctrl`, should work.

![syncselect.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/2664015414-syncselect.png)

I started writing integration tests for all of these but they can become very involved. So taking into account that many of these details might be changed due to user feedback, I thought we could just fix the issues now and write proper tests later.


[homebrew](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/CI%20any%20jobs/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/378/#showFailuresLink) didn't complain

[trusty nvidia](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/CI%20any%20jobs/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/356/#showFailuresLink) didn't complain
summary.html:
This pull request makes it possible to:

  • Align nested models

  • Align a mix of nested models and links, respecting selection order

  • Sync selecting nested models in the 3D scene, model tree and schematic view:

    • Note that on the schematic view the nested models are broken into links, so some tricks were needed to make that work.

    • Without this fix, selecting a nested link in the schematic view also selects it in the 3d scene which opens way for it to be manipulated, we don't want that.

  • Any combination of selecting links, joints and nested models, each selection coming from a different widget, including multi-select holding Ctrl, should work.

I started writing integration tests for all of these but they can become very involved. So taking into account that many of these details might be changed due to user feedback, I thought we could just fix the issues now and write proper tests later.

homebrew didn't complain

trusty nvidia didn't complain

values.description:
Set DepthCamera depthviewport visibility mask so that (GZ_VISIBILITY_GUI | GZ_VISIBILITY_SELECTABLE) models are excluded from rendering.

With the previous visibility mask it was not possible to create a model simultaneously selectable and invisible to the depth camera. With this patch, the depthViewport visibility mask is set the same as the regular camera viewport visibility mask.
values.title: Fix DepthCamera visibility mask flags

summary.raw:
Set DepthCamera depthviewport visibility mask so that (GZ_VISIBILITY_GUI | GZ_VISIBILITY_SELECTABLE) models are excluded from rendering.

With the previous visibility mask it was not possible to create a model simultaneously selectable and invisible to the depth camera. With this patch, the depthViewport visibility mask is set the same as the regular camera viewport visibility mask.
summary.html:
Set DepthCamera depthviewport visibility mask so that (GZ_VISIBILITY_GUI | GZ_VISIBILITY_SELECTABLE) models are excluded from rendering.

With the previous visibility mask it was not possible to create a model simultaneously selectable and invisible to the depth camera. With this patch, the depthViewport visibility mask is set the same as the regular camera viewport visibility mask.

values.description:
I was looking through the `plotting` branch and noticed that there is a test for `common::split` that isn't on default yet, so this moves it to default and does a little extra un-boosting of `boost::split` calls.

The one I didn't try was [gz_log.cc](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/86f56413ee8f0a656982353c54f1347d4b716b68/tools/gz_log.cc?fileviewer=file-view-default#gz_log.cc-94) which calls `boost::split` on a `std::list<std::string>` instead of `std::vector<std::string>`.
values.title: Unboost: replace a few boost::split calls with common::split

summary.raw:
I was looking through the `plotting` branch and noticed that there is a test for `common::split` that isn't on default yet, so this moves it to default and does a little extra un-boosting of `boost::split` calls.

The one I didn't try was [gz_log.cc](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/86f56413ee8f0a656982353c54f1347d4b716b68/tools/gz_log.cc?fileviewer=file-view-default#gz_log.cc-94) which calls `boost::split` on a `std::list<std::string>` instead of `std::vector<std::string>`.
summary.html:
I was looking through the plotting branch and noticed that there is a test for common::split that isn't on default yet, so this moves it to default and does a little extra un-boosting of boost::split calls.

The one I didn't try was gz_log.cc which calls boost::split on a std::list<std::string> instead of std::vector<std::string>.

values.description:
* Fix issue #510

* Add a basic test for editing models via the factory message (mostly because I wanted to document it). More complete tests are needed, as described on issue #1954

A previous version passed the [tests](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/CI%20any%20jobs/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/371/) but wasn't [ABI](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-abichecker-any_to_any-vivid-amd64/341/API_ABI_report/) compatible, so I'll add the ability to disable server renaming to default.

Server generating unique names for lights will come on other PRs.
values.title: Server generates unique model names in case of overlap -> gazebo7

summary.raw:
* Fix issue #510

* Add a basic test for editing models via the factory message (mostly because I wanted to document it). More complete tests are needed, as described on issue #1954

A previous version passed the [tests](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/CI%20any%20jobs/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/371/) but wasn't [ABI](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-abichecker-any_to_any-vivid-amd64/341/API_ABI_report/) compatible, so I'll add the ability to disable server renaming to default.

Server generating unique names for lights will come on other PRs.
summary.html:
• Fix issue #510

  • Add a basic test for editing models via the factory message (mostly because I wanted to document it). More complete tests are needed, as described on issue #1954

A previous version passed the tests but wasn't ABI compatible, so I'll add the ability to disable server renaming to default.

Server generating unique names for lights will come on other PRs.

values.description:
* Addresses issue #510

* See also pull request #2296 targeted at `gazebo7`

* This PR adds the `allow_renaming` field to `factory` messages

Some CI results from before merging with default:

* [homebrew](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/CI%20any%20jobs/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/393/) has no unexpected failures

* [gpu](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/CI%20any%20jobs/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/371/) has no new failures
values.title: Server generates unique model names in case of overlap -> default
